text:
<@U5TCAFTD3>

Just to add another voice to this but I feel there is much more to lose than switching costs!

Slack is good for essentially ephemeral reaction within a 24 hour window but FoC topics desperately want to be thoughtful threads that  can last months and for old topics to be bumped as new research emerges.

elements.text:

text: yup .. I believe that those threads people start don't show up as 'new' or 'unread' when people add to them, unless you've replied yourself? (the fact that I don't know gives some idea of how opaque I'm finding it)

text:
how about we start lots of Channels? One for each of the fine-grained themes that re-occur here? e.g.:
- better IDEs for techies
- declarative vs imperative
- state vs pure/monads
- spreadsheet derivatives
- history of programming

text: and NO side threads!

elements.text: and NO side threads!

text: <@UE6EFEPTQ> You’re right. You’d either have to reply to a thread, or use the “Follow Message/Thread” feature to subscribe (it’s under the three dots button). But then you’d have to hope that everybody replies in-thread.

elements.text: You’re right. You’d either have to reply to a thread, or use the “Follow Message/Thread” feature to subscribe (it’s under the three dots button). But then you’d have to hope that everybody replies in-thread.

text: On the other hand, if you’re also subscribed to the channel, you’ll get new top-level messages anyway.

elements.text: On the other hand, if you’re also subscribed to the channel, you’ll get new top-level messages anyway.

text: ah .. thx for the follow thread tip!

elements.text: ah .. thx for the follow thread tip!

text: threads are still ephemeral, though - I can't believe I'll be seeing any new posts to the threads I've just gone around following

elements.text: threads are still ephemeral, though - I can't believe I'll be seeing any new posts to the threads I've just gone around following

text: there's not really an incentive to revisit 'old' (i.e. more than 1 day) threads

text:
by channel organization assumes that people can know the topic before discussion, and can stay inside that topic during it.

That's usually not the case, topic get diverted quite easily.

text: <@UE6EFEPTQ> Not sure understand… once I follow threads the All Threads View brings up old threads automatically, if there are new messages. So you wouldn’t have to manually look for threads with new messages, if that’s what you were implying…?

elements.text: Not sure understand… once I follow threads the All Threads View brings up old threads automatically, if there are new messages. So you wouldn’t have to manually look for threads with new messages, if that’s what you were implying…?

text: learning a lot about threads :smile:

elements.text: learning a lot about threads

text: It’s a little unfortunate that there is so much to learn about it.

elements.text: It’s a little unfortunate that there is so much to learn about it.

text: <@U5STGTB3J> yes, but I mean I'm not expecting to see any updates to the threads I've now followed. That's because the whole Slack experience discourages people going back to 'old' threads, more than a day old, and carrying on

elements.text: yes, but I mean I'm not expecting to see any updates to the threads I've now followed. That's because the whole Slack experience discourages people going back to 'old' threads, more than a day old, and carrying on

text:
To clarify, the reason I want to stick with Slack is that there is no clear alternative that seems clearly better to me. Every time one is proposed, I look into it and have decided that it's <= to Slack or so close that it's hard to tell. (Unfortunately, I haven't been writing down this research on each alternative, so I can't share it with y'all. This is problem for me too, because often forget that I reviewed an alternative and have to re look into it because I forgot why I didn't like it. I should probably start putting those reviews somewhere...) I am no Slack devotee, and will be thrilled to move platforms when there's an alternative that's clearly better. If you are particularly excited about one alternative in particular, please share and I'll review :slightly_smiling_face:

I'm currently dreaming of a mix between a forum and a chat app, so it feels casual like Slack but you can also go deep into conversations that stay put. I think an infinite nesting interface a la reddit or HN could be cool. The channels and single-level threads that we have here in Slack feel arbitrarily shallow. (There is no 2 or 3 in computer science. Only 0, 1 or many.)

(Unfortunately, I haven't been writing down this research on each alternative, so I can't share it with y'all. This is problem for me too, because often forget that I reviewed an alternative and have to re look into it because I forgot why I didn't like it. I should probably start putting those reviews somewhere...) I am no Slack devotee, and will be thrilled to move platforms when there's an alternative that's clearly better. If you are particularly excited about one alternative in particular, please share and I'll review

text: why don't we move the "share an interesting link" task to a subreddit to have the nested comments and permanence and keep slack for random conversations? we share it on reddit and put the link here to notify everyone that there's a new thing over there (maybe there's a slack integration for that)

text: I worry it's one social tool too many. I'm already in 17 Slacks, HN, and Twitter...

text: I'm curious what you think of Zulip, if you've taken a look! It's not perfect, but the threading model is the best I've seen for creating a blend between chat & forum.

elements.text: I'm curious what you think of Zulip, if you've taken a look! It's not perfect, but the threading model is the best I've seen for creating a blend between chat & forum.

text: Great question! Do you have access to a Zulip you could add me to? I'd love to play around. Let me go re-read their homeage to remember what I thought about it...

elements.text: Great question! Do you have access to a Zulip you could add me to? I'd love to play around. Let me go re-read their homeage to remember what I thought about it...

text: The threading level is still just two: one for the channel and one for topics. Slack has the same: one for channel and one for a message in that channel. Do you think Zulip's second level of threading is more intuitive?

elements.text: The threading level is still just two: one for the channel and one for topics. Slack has the same: one for channel and one for a message in that channel. Do you think Zulip's second level of threading is more intuitive?

text: I don't have a Zulip for you, since the only one I'm on is Recurse Center's. But maybe I'll set up a demo chat we can play with.

elements.text: I don't have a Zulip for you, since the only one I'm on is Recurse Center's. But maybe I'll set up a demo chat we can play with.

text: no worries, I can set it up :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: no worries, I can set it up

text: You're right that the threading is flat. But the interface makes it used in a fundamentally different way. I tried to write out a sentence or two to explain it, but we should just play with it and I can show you. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: You're right that the threading is flat. But the interface makes it used in a fundamentally different way. I tried to write out a sentence or two to explain it, but we should just play with it and I can show you.

text: I'm joining here to get a sense <https://chat.zulip.org/login/>

elements.text: I'm joining here to get a sense

text: (Basically, it's a setup which makes conversations actually stay in topics, so topics become a useful way of having multiple conversations in a single channel, instead of a weird side-feature like Slack makes them.)

elements.text: (Basically, it's a setup which makes conversations actually stay in topics, so topics become a useful way of having multiple conversations in a single channel, instead of a weird side-feature like Slack makes them.)

text: Huh, this is actually pretty great... I'm going to have to noodle on it...

text: It's not infinite threading but it takes the Slack threading and makes it the default way to use the app, so there no confusion like there is now with threading

elements.text: It's not infinite threading but it takes the Slack threading and makes it the default way to use the app, so there no confusion like there is now with threading

text:
Pros:

• better threading support

Cons:

• less bots, including <@UFQ0XSFH6> <@UD6BTU55K> which we use
• having to switch, which would be a small headache, and would lose direct messages

elements.text:

text: I like your description.

elements.text: I like your description.

text: Yeah, I'm not in a position right now to advocate for a switch. I definitely think it's a contender though! And it makes me want to look for similar threading in other apps, though I'm skeptical any of them have anything like Zulip.

elements.text: Yeah, I'm not in a position right now to advocate for a switch. I definitely think it's a contender though! And it makes me want to look for similar threading in other apps, though I'm skeptical any of them have anything like Zulip.

text: (Fun back-story which may or may not be 100% accurate: Zulip started as a modern interface to an MIT chat protocol called Zephyr, which dates back to the '80s. Zephyr is where this stream/topic thing comes from.)

elements.text: (Fun back-story which may or may not be 100% accurate: Zulip started as a modern interface to an MIT chat protocol called Zephyr, which dates back to the '80s. Zephyr is where this stream/topic thing comes from.)
